Package org.quickconnect

QCJava is a free, open source, application framework for Java available under the BSD license.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
ControlObject The ControlObject is an Interface that all control stack objects must implement.
 

Class Summary
QuickConnect The QuickConnect class is used to create control stacks and execute them.
 

Package org.quickconnect Description

QCJava is a free, open source, application framework for Java available under the BSD license. You may use it for open or closed source applications. You may give your application away free or charge for it. The BSD license has no restrictions regarding these topics. This Framework is also included in the QuickConnect Android application template.

Command => Response

QCJava is a Command => Response based framework. You use it by deciding on a command string and mapping a series of control objects to the command. This series of control objects is know as a command stack.

The QuickConnect class has static methods that follow the mapCommandTo** pattern. These methods are used to create the stacks. Each stack consists of a series of optional types.
  • Validation Control Objects (ValCOs)
  • Business Control Objects (BCOs)
  • View Control Objects (VCOs)
Your application logic will consist of a single stack for each trigger in the UI. Such triggers are usually button selections, etc. for Android and Java SE or http requests for Java EE.

An example stack to handle logging in might look something like this:
  1. UnamePwordValCO - validate the user name and password by checking length, special character requirements, etc.
  2. GetUserBCO - query a database, remote or local, and retrieve a user with the given user name and password
  3. GetDataBCO - query a remote service and retrieve information to show the user
  4. WelcomeVCO - update the view to show the results of the login

    The number of each of these types of control objects varies from zero to many.

    I have attempted to make this framework as easy to use, small, and fast as I could. The jar file is currently 8k in size. Any suggestions would be appreciated.

    Lee S. Barney, Author.

    For more information regarding the QuickConnect Family, see the QuickConnect web site.
